title: What is Machine Learning?
description: Understand the basics of machine learning -- how computers learn from data instead of following hardcoded rules.

content.question: How does machine learning differ from traditional programming?
options: In ML, the computer learns patterns from data instead of following explicit step-by-step instructions
ML programs run faster than traditional programs
ML doesn't require any data to work
content.explanation: In traditional programming, a developer writes specific rules (if X then Y). In machine learning, you give the computer examples (data) and it figures out the patterns on its own. For example, instead of writing rules to detect spam, you show the ML model thousands of spam and non-spam emails and it learns what makes an email spam.

content.prompt: Match each type of machine learning to its description.

pairs.right: Learns from labeled examples (input + correct answer)
Finds hidden patterns in data without labels
Learns by trial and error, receiving rewards or penalties
The dataset used to teach the model

content.prompt: Put these steps in order to build a simple ML model that predicts house prices.
items: Collect data about houses (size, location, number of rooms, sale price)
Clean and prepare the data (remove errors, handle missing values)
Split the data into training set and test set
Train the model on the training data
Evaluate the model's accuracy on the test set
Use the model to predict prices for new houses
content.explanation: Building an ML model follows a structured process: gather data, clean it, split it so you can test fairly, train the model, check how well it works, and then use it in the real world.

content.sentence: In supervised learning, the model learns from _____ data, which means each example comes with the correct _____.

questions.question: In traditional programming, what two things are combined to produce output?
In machine learning, what does the learning algorithm produce?

title: Training, Inference & Lifecycle
description: Explore the ML lifecycle -- from training a model on data, to using it for predictions, to deploying it in the real world.

content.question: What is an 'epoch' in machine learning training?
options: One complete pass through the entire training dataset
The final accuracy score of a model
A type of neural network layer
The time it takes to deploy a model
content.explanation: An epoch is one full cycle through all the training data. Models usually train for many epochs -- imagine reading a textbook multiple times to learn the material better. Each pass helps the model refine its understanding.

content.prompt: Match each ML training concept to its meaning.

pairs.right: The process where a model learns patterns from data
Using a trained model to make predictions on new data
The model memorizes training data but fails on new data
The model is too simple to capture patterns in the data
Measures how wrong the model's predictions are

content.prompt: Put these stages of the ML model lifecycle in order.
items: Define the problem and collect relevant data
Train the model and tune hyperparameters
Evaluate model performance on test data
Monitor performance and retrain when needed
content.explanation: The ML lifecycle is iterative: you start by defining what you want to predict, prepare your data, train and evaluate, deploy to production, and then continuously monitor. If performance drops, you retrain with new data.

content.sentence: When a model performs well on training data but poorly on new unseen data, it is called _____. The opposite problem, where the model is too simple to learn, is called _____.

questions.question: What role does the loss function play during training?
options: It provides error feedback to help the model improve
It deploys the model to production
questions.answer: It provides error feedback to help the model improve

questions.question: During inference, what goes into the trained model?

content.question: A model trained to recognize cats was shown 10,000 cat photos and now identifies every cat perfectly -- but fails to recognize cats in real-world photos with different backgrounds. What is this problem called?
content.explanation: This is overfitting -- the model memorized the training data (including specific backgrounds and lighting) instead of learning generalizable features of cats. It performs great on training data but poorly on new, unseen data. Think of it like a student who memorizes test answers but can't apply concepts to new problems.

title: Classification & Regression
description: Learn the two main types of ML predictions: classifying things into categories and predicting continuous numbers.

content.question: Which of the following is a classification task?
options: Determining whether an email is spam or not spam
Estimating the price of a house
content.explanation: Classification assigns data to categories (spam vs. not spam, cat vs. dog, positive vs. negative). The other options predict continuous numbers (temperature, price, revenue), which makes them regression tasks.

content.prompt: Match each real-world task to whether it is classification or regression.

pairs.left: Is this photo a cat or dog?
How much will this house sell for?
What will the stock price be tomorrow?
Which genre does this movie belong to?
How many minutes until the bus arrives?

content.sentence: _____ predicts discrete categories (like 'cat' or 'dog'), while _____ predicts continuous numerical values (like price or temperature).

content.prompt: Put these steps in order to evaluate a classification model using a confusion matrix.
items: Train the classification model on labeled training data
Run the model on the test data to get predictions
Compare each prediction to the actual correct label
Count true positives, true negatives, false positives, and false negatives
Calculate metrics like accuracy and precision from the counts
content.explanation: A confusion matrix is built by comparing predictions vs. actual labels. You count how many the model got right (true positives/negatives) and wrong (false positives/negatives), then use those counts to calculate performance metrics.

content.diagram:
Confusion Matrix (Spam Classifier)

                          Predicted
                    ┌─────────┬──────────┐
                    │  Spam   │ Not Spam │
         ┌──────────┼─────────┼──────────┤
         │  Spam    │   45    │    5     │
  Actual │          │  (TP)   │  (FN)    │
         ├──────────┼─────────┼──────────┤
         │ Not Spam │    3    │   47     │
         │          │  (FP)   │  (TN)    │
         └──────────┴─────────┴──────────┘

         TP = True Positive    FP = False Positive
         FN = False Negative   TN = True Negative
